item.title: Hundreds of Minnesota Businesses on Strike in Protest Against ICE
item.description: Thousands of protesters shut down streets throughout Minneapolis-St. Paul to demand that federal immigration agents end their weekslong crackdown. Businesses closed in solidarity.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel, Talya Minsberg, Maia Coleman and Summer Rabold
item.media:description: Thousands of protesters shut down parts of Minneapolis and St. Paul on Friday as hundreds of businesses closed their doors.

item.title: FBI Agent Resigns After Trying to Investigate ICE Officer in Renee Good Shooting
item.description: The resignation of the agent, Tracee Mergen, was only the latest shock wave to have emerged from the Justice Department’s handling of the shooting of Renee Good.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Police and federal agents at the scene where an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent fatally shot Renee Good in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Are Republicans Growing a Little Uneasy About the ICE Raids?
item.description: Polls, careful remarks from JD Vance and chats with voters all point to some wariness.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

item.title: Winter Storm Forecast: Where the Ice Could Hit Worst
item.description: Even a little ice can be far more dangerous than snow in some places.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones

item.title: Trump’s Turnabout on Greenland Shows the Limits of His Coercive Powers
item.description: President Trump’s faith in his ability to wring concessions by taking maximalist positions was on full display this week. So were the costs, as he splintered NATO and then undercut his credibility by climbing down from his threats.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump on Air Force One en route to Washington on Thursday night.

item.title: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark Visits Greenland
item.description: The trip by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen to the Danish territory came amid pressure from President Trump and appeared to have been meant as reassurance to Greenlanders.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, in the tan coat; the mayor of Nuuk, Greenland, Avaaraq Olsenand; and Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen of Greenland set off on a highly choreographed walk through the city on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s Push to Take Greenland Holds Promise and Peril for Putin
item.description: If the United States under President Trump starts acting as if it’s Russia, where does that leave President Vladimir V. Putin?
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Anchorage, in August.

item.title: Trump Wants to Build More U.S. Military Bases in Greenland. How Many Are There Now?
item.description: The U.S. once maintained more than a dozen. Now it has one. President Trump wants more.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Thomas Traasdahl/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse – Getty Images
item.media:description: At the Pituffik Space Base in Greenland, the United States has 150 people who run missile defense and space surveillance.

item.title: At March for Life, Some Abortion Opponents Want More From Trump
item.description: At the March for Life, Vice President JD Vance acknowledged “a fear that some of you have that not enough progress has been made.”
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion opponents gathered in Washington on Friday for the annual March for Life.

item.title: Renée Fleming Won’t Perform at Kennedy Center Concerts
item.description: The soprano, who previously resigned as an artistic adviser, was scheduled to sing with the National Symphony Orchestra in May.
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Bailey
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Renée Fleming was honored by the Kennedy Center in 2023.

item.title: U.S. Says First Boat Strike Since Maduro’s Capture Killed 2 in Eastern Pacific
item.description: The U.S. Southern Command said it had asked the Coast Guard to search for one survivor.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: U.S. Southern Command, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from a video released by the U.S. Southern Command showing a vessel accused of trafficking drugs in the eastern Pacific Ocean on Friday.

item.title: An Unlikely Source of Crypto Innovation: Afghanistan
item.description: The repressive Taliban government is suspicious of the internet. But a start-up in the country is building blockchain-based tools to transform humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker and Emile Ducke
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local beneficiaries wait in line to receive their aid payments as part of a Mercy Corps pilot project using HesabPay, a blockchain-based payment system developed in Afghanistan, in the town of Halfaya, Syria.

item.title: Colorado Authorities Confirm Suicide by Hunter S. Thompson
item.description: After a monthslong review, investigators have concluded that “all speculative theories could not be substantiated.”
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango

item.title: TikTok Updates Its Terms and Conditions in the U.S.
item.description: The changes came after the app’s Chinese parent company spun out an American entity to run TikTok in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: The new version of TikTok’s privacy policy states that, if users enable location services, the company can collect approximate or precise location information.

item.title: Ryan Wedding, Canadian Ex-Snowboarder Accused of Running Drug Ring, Is Arrested
item.description: Ryan Wedding, 44, who competed in snowboarding in the 2002 Winter Olympics, has been charged with murder and smuggling cocaine into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic snowboarder, has been charged with smuggling cocaine into the United States and with murder.

item.title: 5 Arrested in Shooting of Indiana Judge Steven Meyer and His Wife
item.description: The police said the attack was part of a plot to kill Judge Steven Meyer to halt a trial he was to conduct. He and his wife were injured but are recovering.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Steven Meyer, a judge of the Tippecanoe County Superior Court, and his wife, Kimberly, were shot on Sunday at their home in Lafayette, Ind.

item.title: John Brodie, a Star Quarterback for the 49ers, Dies at 90
item.description: He endured years of frustration before emerging as the N.F.L.’s most valuable player.
item.dc:creator: William Yardley and Frank Litsky
item.media:credit: Digital First Media Group/Oakland Tribune, via Getty Images

item.title: Towering Snowdrifts Bury City on Remote Russian Peninsula
item.description: It’s the biggest snowfall the Kamchatka Peninsula has experienced in nearly 60 years.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:description: Dealing with the piles of snow in Petropavlovsk‑Kamchatsky, Russia, has been a challenge, residents said.

item.title: Is This Who Trump Meant by the ‘Worst of the Worst’?
item.description: The columnist Jamelle Bouie argues that the Trump administration’s immigration policy has more in common with ethnic cleansing than actual immigration enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie and Ingrid Holmquist
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Trump Crackup
item.description: Events are being propelled by one man’s damaged psyche.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: For His Next Act, Darren Walker Is Heading to Hollywood
item.description: Anonymous Content, a production company whose top investor is Laurene Powell Jobs’s Emerson Collective, has named Darren Walker as president and chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nate Langston Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Storytelling shapes culture, informs how we see ourselves and how we see the humanity in others,” Darren Walker said of his move to Anonymous Content.

item.title: Couple Receive $200,000 Settlement After ‘Pungent’ Indian Food Complaint
item.description: The University of Colorado, Boulder, denied liability in the civil rights lawsuit, which the couple filed after a comment about a dish that one of them was heating in an office microwave.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: What Happened At the Funeral For Fashion Designer Valentino
item.description: The designer Valentino Garavani, who died on Monday at 93, was celebrated in Rome, a city that he “embodied,” according to its mayor.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The coffin of the fashion designer Valentino Garavani arriving at his funeral in Rome on Friday.
